hanzi-su-wiki:
冒

Значения

Отваживаться, решаться; осквернять

Мнемоника

Идти на риск, надвинув на глаза 目 шапку 日, чтобы было не так страшно. Авантюризм.

Варианты

冐
purpleculture_pinyin:
mào
to emit; to give off; to send out (or up, forth); to brave; to face; reckless; to falsely adopt (sb's identity etc); to feign; (literary) to cover
излучать; испускать; отправить (или вверх, вперед); храбрый; к лицу; безрассудный; ложно заимствовать (личность SB и т. д.); притворяться; (литературный) покрыть
rtega_mnemonic:
冒冒RS冐risk, brave, dare, incautious, rash
  • RS. a hat 冃 over the eyes 目: rash, ready to brave many risks
purpleculture_info: Pictophonetic: 冃 indicates the sound; 目 (A man ⺼ wearing a helmet 由) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
假冒伪劣 [ jiǎ mào wěi liè ]: cheap quality counterfeit (goods); low-quality commodities
冒险 [ mào xiǎn ]: to take risks; to take chances; foray; adventure
假冒 [ jiǎ mào ]: to impersonate; to pose as (someone else); to counterfeit; to palm off (a fake as a genuine)
感冒 [ gǎn mào ]: to catch cold; (common) cold; Classifiers: 场 ; (coll.) to be interested in (often used in the negative); (Tw) to detest; can't stand
冒充 [ mào chōng ]: to feign; to pretend to be; to pass oneself off as
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿱ Above to below
    • 日 [ rì ] sun; day; daytime
    • 目 [ mù ] eye; to look, to see; division, topic
heisig_chinese_memo: Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's risky!
heisig_story: Remember when you were young and your mother told you never to look directly into the sun for fear you might burn out your eyes? Probably you were foolish enough to risk a quick glance once or twice; but just as probably, you passed that bit of folk wisdom on to someone else as you grew older. Here, too, the kanji that has a sun above and an eye right below looking up at it has the meaning of risk (see frame 12).
Keyword_KANJIDIC: risk, face, defy, dare, damage, assume (a name)
Keyword_KANJIDIC_ru: риск, лицо, Defy, дерзайте, повреждение, предположим (имя)
koohiiStory1: Don´t look at the sun directly with your eyes, it´s risky!
koohiiStory2: You´ll risk your eyesight if you look up at the sun.
jp_example_words:
冒頭(ぼうとう): beginning, start, outset
冒険(ぼうけん): risk, venture, adventure
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: When the sun gets in your eye, I dare you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Looking at the sun straight on hurts. It’s bad for your eyes and burns your brain. Imagine how painful it is to stare at the sun.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: After you’ve blinded yourself from the dare of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go bowling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Picture yourself bowling without the power of sight. It would be awfully difficult to do well. You’d just have to concentrate really hard on the sound of the pins and determine where you need to throw the ball.
Ru_Meaning: risk, face, defy, dare, damage, assume (a name)
Ru_trainchinese:

mào: (графема) оскорблять, нарушать; не считаться с; выдавать себя за другого человека
Kanshudo_mnemonic: if the sun's (日) shining in your eyes (目) you have to brave it
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: Don't look at the sun directly with your eyes, it's risky!
humanum_full_description_en:
Inscriptions from "冃" from "目", "冃" is like a hat, and " eye " is like an eye. Ancients often used eyes to represent the head, and the whole character is like a hat on a head. The original meaning is headwear, that is, hat. Bronze writing is used as a person's name. The "冃" of the bamboo slips of the Warring States period became " Yin ", and the " me " or " self " was changed to " self ". One said that " self " is a shorthand for " first ", like wearing a hat.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period are used as a verb to mean wearing a hat, "Guodianjian. "Tao of Tang Yu" Jane 25-26: "The ancient saint is twenty (twenty) and Mao (cap), thirty (30) and (has) family." "Mao (cap)" means crowning, meaning It is said that in ancient times, the saint was crowned as an adult at the age of 20 and married at the age of 30. "Book of Rites. "Qu Li": "Twenty is weak, crown." Also used as a name, "Tsinghua Jian Yi. "Chuju" Jian 7: "Zhi Fen (蚡) Mao (Xiong) Shuai (rate) moved from Ruo (鄀) to live in Fen." "Fang Mao" is the monarch of the Chu Kingdom, namely the king of Chu Li, formerly known as "Xiong Rate" , " Pang " and " Fen " are both place names, meaning that Fen Maoxiong moved from Pang to Fen. "Mandarin. Zheng Yu. "The End of King Ping, Qin, Jin, Qi, and Chu Daixing": "Chu Pingmao is the beginning of Qipu", Wei Zhao's note: "Mao, the grandson of Chu Jihuan, the son of Ruo Ao bears the lead."

Examples of the original meaning of " mo " in the handed down literature are like "Han Shu. "Science from Xue Ping and Peng Chuan": "In the first year of the Yuan Dynasty, a man rode in a yellow trolley, built a yellow scorpion, dressed in a yellow coat, dressed in a yellow scorpion, and called himself the prince of Wei." Covering its head." "旐" is a flag, "襜褕" is an ancient form of clothing. The things that this self-proclaimed Prince Wei wears on his head, body, and uses are bright yellow. Another example is "New Tang Book. Yufuzhi: "Those who take a white gauze, look at the court, hear the lawsuit, and see the guests' clothes." " Mao " was later added with the meaning " scarf " as a " hat " to indicate this meaning, and " taking " It is used for its extended meaning. See " hat ".

There are also examples in ancient books where "to take " as a verb to mean wearing a hat, such as "Zhan Guo Ce. "Han Ceyi": "Shandong's pawns are attacked by armor to fight." " Bo " is a helmet, and "Mao" means wearing a helmet. "The Book of Later Han Dynasty. Yufu Zhixia: "Ancient cave dwelling in the wild, with furry clothes and fake skins, there is no system."

" Mao " is worn on the head, extending the meaning of covering and covering. "Jade articles. "Xianbu": "Come, cover also." Such as "Poetry. Bei Feng. "Sun and Moon": "The sun resides in the moon, and when you go down the earth, it is a risk." "Mao Zhuan": "The sun is like the moon, and it shines upon it." " House " and " Zhu " are modal particles. "anthology. Cao Zijian's "Poems of Public Swallows": "Qiulan was taken by Changban, and Zhu Hua took the green pond."

Wearing a hat on one's head means that the hat covers the top of the head as well as the hat on the head. Therefore, "to pretend " is also extended to the meaning of wearing on and off, as in "Historical Records. Biographies of Sima Xiangru: "Resolve the white blade, brave the arrow, do not hesitate, do not turn back." It further expresses disregard and risk (danger), such as "Hou Han Shu. The Biography of Deng, Zhang, Xu, Zhang and Hu: "Wearing that the car is driving into Jiangling, I thought it was not appropriate to take risks, and the post horse would advise." "Selected Works. Cao Zijian "Ask for self-examination": "Because of daring to risk his ugliness and show his loyalty, he must know that he is laughed at by the courtiers."

" Risk " means violated, offended. Such as "Warring States Policy. "Chu Ceyi": "(Menggu) then abandoned himself in the Moshan Mountain. There has been no risk so far." Bao Biao's note: "Courage means breaking the law." "Historical Records. "The Family of the Uncle Wu": "Then he attacked Chu with five thousand men. Chu's army was defeated and left."

" Risk " means counterfeit, posing. Such as "Historical Records. Biography of Ranger: "The young man from the Jin Dynasty didn't know how to solve it, so he wanted to get out." "Han Shu. "The Biography of Wei Qinghuo Qubing": "Qing has the same mother-in-law Wei Changjun and her sister-in-law. The son-in-law was lucky to Emperor Wu from the family of Princess Pingyang, so Qing Mao's surname was Wei."

" Making " also means greed. Such as "Shang Shu. "Thai Oath": "Today, the king of Shang accepts, Fu respects the heavens, sends disasters to the people, indulges in color, dares to tyranny." "Kong Chuan": "Indulges in alcohol, and pretends to be female sex." Kong Yingdashu: "Come on Training is also greedy." "Zuo Zhuan. Eighteenth Year of Wengong": "The Jinyun family has talented scholars, greedy for food and bribery."

" Mao " also means to penetrate outwards and upwards, such as smoking, sweating, etc., which is the post-uprising. An example is the Northern Song Dynasty Su Shi's "Raising Vegetable Garden after Rain": "White sock-like lambs and dolphins, croaking out of the soil." Chapter 86 of "Dream of Red Mansions": "The uncle took a bowl and smashed his head, and he immediately bled. underground."
humanum_short_description_en: Bronze inscriptions from "冃" from "目", "冃" is like a hat, and " eye " is like an eye. Ancients often used eyes to represent the head, and the whole character is like a head wearing a hat. The original meaning is headwear, that is, hat. Extension means covering, offending, impersonating, etc.
humanum_full_description:
金文從「冃」從「目」，「冃」象帽子之形，「目」象眼睛，古人往往用眼睛來代表頭部，全字象頭戴帽子之形。本義是頭衣，即帽子。金文用作人名。戰國竹簡「冃」訛變為「尹」形，「目」或訛變為「自」。一說「自」是「首」的簡寫，象頭戴帽子。

　　戰國竹簡用作動詞，表示戴帽子，《郭店簡．唐虞之道》簡25-26：「古者聖人廿（二十）而冒（帽），卅（三十）而又（有）家」，「冒（帽）」有加冠之意，意謂古時聖人二十歲加冠為成人，三十歲成家立室。《禮記．曲禮》：「二十曰弱，冠。」又用作人名，《清華簡一．楚居》簡7：「至焚（蚡）冒酓（熊）帥（率）自箬（鄀）徙居焚。」「蚡冒」是楚國君主，即楚厲王，原名「熊率」，「鄀」、「焚」都是地名，意謂焚冒熊率從鄀遷居於焚。《國語．鄭語．平王之末秦晉齊楚代興》：「楚蚠冒於是乎始啟濮」，韋昭注：「冒，楚季紃之孫，若敖之子熊率。」

　　傳世文獻中「冒」用本義的例子如《漢書．雋疏于薛平彭傳》：「始元五年，有一男子乘黃犢車，建黃旐，衣黃襜褕，著黃冒，詣北闕，自謂衛太子。」顏師古注：「冒，所以覆冒其首。」「旐」是旗子，「襜褕」是古代一種單衣。這個自稱衛太子之人頭上所戴、身上所穿以及所用之物都是明黃色。又如《新唐書．輿服志》：「白紗冒者，視朝、聽訟、宴見賓客之服也。」「冒」後來又加上意符「巾」作「帽」以表示此義項，而「冒」則用於其引申義。參見「帽」。

　　古書中亦有「冒」作動詞表示戴帽子的例子，如《戰國策．韓策一》：「山東之卒被甲冒冑以會戰。」「冑」是頭盔，「冒冑」就是戴頭盔。《後漢書．輿服志下》：「上古穴居而野處，衣毛而冒皮，未有制度。」

　　「冒」戴於頭上，引申出覆蓋、籠罩的意思。《玉篇．冃部》：「冒，覆也。」如《詩．邶風．日月》：「日居月諸，下土是冒。」《毛傳》：「日乎月乎，照臨之也。」「居」和「諸」是語氣助詞。《文選．曹子建〈公讌詩〉》：「秋蘭被長坂，朱華冒綠池。」

　　頭戴帽子既是帽子覆蓋頭頂，也是頭上頂著帽子，故「冒」亦引申為頂著、冒著的意思，如《史記．司馬相如列傳》：「解白刃，冒流矢，義不反顧，計不旋踵。」進一步表示不顧、冒著（危險），如《後漢書．鄧張徐張胡列傳》：「聞車駕當進幸江陵，以為不宜冒險遠，驛馬上諫。」《文選．曹子建〈求自試表〉》：「是以敢冒其醜而獻其忠，必知為朝士所笑。」

　　「冒」表示觸犯、冒犯。如《戰國策．楚策一》：「（蒙穀）遂自棄於磨山之中，至今無冒。」鮑彪注：「冒，謂犯法。」《史記．吳太伯世家》：「遂以其部五千人襲冒楚，楚兵大敗，走。」

　　「冒」表示假冒、冒充。如《史記．游俠列傳》：「臨晉籍少公素不知解，解冒，因求出關。」《漢書．衛青霍去病傳》：「青有同母兄衛長君及姊子夫，子夫自平陽公主家得幸武帝，故青冒姓為衛氏。」

　　「冒」亦表示貪婪。如《尚書．泰誓》：「今商王受，弗敬上天，降災下民，沈湎冒色，敢行暴虐。」《孔傳》：「沈湎嗜酒，冒亂女色。」孔穎達疏：「冒訓貪也。」《左傳．文公十八年》：「縉雲氏有不才子，貪于飲食，冒于貨賄。」

　　「冒」還表示向外透、往上升，如冒煙、冒汗等，乃後起義。例子如北宋蘇軾〈雨後行菜圃〉：「白菘類羔豚，冒土出蹯掌。」《紅樓夢》第86回：「大爺拿碗就砸他的腦袋，一下子就冒了血了，躺在地下。」
humanum_short_description: 金文從「冃」從「目」，「冃」象帽子之形，「目」象眼睛，古人往往用眼睛來代表頭部，全字象頭戴帽子之形。本義是頭衣，即帽子。引申表示覆蓋、觸犯、冒充等義。
_purpleculture_dictionary_orig_full:
冒
Pinyin: mào
English Definition: to emit; to give off; to send out (or up, forth); to brave; to face; reckless; to falsely adopt (sb's identity etc); to feign; (literary) to cover
Total strokes: 9; Radical: 冂
Pictophonetic: 冃 indicates the sound; 目 (A man ⺼ wearing a helmet 由) conveys the meaning.
Character Formation:
  • ⿱ Above to below
    • 日 [ rì ] sun; day; daytime
    • 目 [ mù ] eye; to look, to see; division, topic
Step by Step Stroke Sequence: Download Customize Pin it
Example Words:
假冒伪劣 [ jiǎ mào wěi liè ]: cheap quality counterfeit (goods); low-quality commodities
冒险 [ mào xiǎn ]: to take risks; to take chances; foray; adventure
假冒 [ jiǎ mào ]: to impersonate; to pose as (someone else); to counterfeit; to palm off (a fake as a genuine)
感冒 [ gǎn mào ]: to catch cold; (common) cold; Classifiers: 场 ; (coll.) to be interested in (often used in the negative); (Tw) to detest; can't stand
冒充 [ mào chōng ]: to feign; to pretend to be; to pass oneself off as
More: 冒* | *冒 | *冒*

冒冒RS 冐 risk, brave, dare, incautious, rash
  • RS. a hat 冃 over the eyes 目: rash, ready to brave many risks
Chinese Definition:
Pictophonetic: 冃 indicates the sound; 目 (A man ⺼ wearing a helmet 由) conveys the meaning.
  • ⿱ Above to below
    • 日 [ rì ] sun; day; daytime
    • 目 [ mù ] eye; to look, to see; division, topic
①向外透或往上升：冒烟(a。烟往上升；b。发怒)。冒汗。冒尖。
②不顾(恶劣的环境或危险等)，顶着：冒雨。冒险。冒死。
③不加小心，鲁莽，冲撞：冒失。冒昧。冒进(不顾具体条件，急躁进行)。
④用假的充当真的，假托：冒牌。冒充。冒名顶替。
⑤复盖：“先设一铁板，其上以松脂、蜡和纸灰之类冒之”。
⑥贪污：“贪于饮食，冒于货贿”。
⑦古同“帽”。
⑧古同“瑁”，玳瑁。
⑨姓氏。

Probably you were foolish enough to risk a quick glance once or twice; but just as probably, you passed that bit of folk wisdom on to someone else as you grew older. 金文從「 冃 」從「 目 」，「 冃 」象帽子之形，「 目 」象眼睛，古人往往用眼睛來代表頭部，全字象頭戴帽子之形。本義是頭衣，即帽子。金文用作人名。戰國竹簡「 冃 」訛變為「 尹 」形，「 目 」或訛變為「 自 」。一說「 自 」是「 首 」的簡寫，象頭戴帽子。 戰國竹簡用作動詞，表示戴帽子，《郭店簡．唐虞之道》簡25-26：「古者聖人廿（二十）而冒（帽），卅（三十）而又（有）家」，「冒（帽）」有加冠之意，意謂古時聖人二十歲加冠為成人，三十歲成家立室。《禮記．曲禮》：「二十曰弱，冠。」又用作人名，《清華簡一．楚居》簡7：「至焚（蚡）冒酓（熊）帥（率）自箬（鄀）徙居焚。」「蚡冒」是楚國君主，即楚厲王，原名「熊率」，「 鄀 」、「 焚 」都是地名，意謂焚冒熊率從鄀遷居於焚。《國語．鄭語．平王之末秦晉齊楚代興》：「楚蚠冒於是乎始啟濮」，韋昭注：「冒，楚季紃之孫，若敖之子熊率。」 傳世文獻中「 冒 」用本義的例子如《漢書．雋疏于薛平彭傳》：「始元五年，有一男子乘黃犢車，建黃旐，衣黃襜褕，著黃冒，詣北闕，自謂衛太子。」顏師古注：「冒，所以覆冒其首。」「 旐 」是旗子，「襜褕」是古代一種單衣。這個自稱衛太子之人頭上所戴、身上所穿以及所用之物都是明黃色。又如《新唐書．輿服志》：「白紗冒者，視朝、聽訟、宴見賓客之服也。」「 冒 」後來又加上意符「 巾 」作「 帽 」以表示此義項，而「 冒 」則用於其引申義。參見「 帽 」。 古書中亦有「 冒 」作動詞表示戴帽子的例子，如《戰國策．韓策一》：「山東之卒被甲冒冑以會戰。」「 冑 」是頭盔，「冒冑」就是戴頭盔。《後漢書．輿服志下》：「上古穴居而野處，衣毛而冒皮，未有制度。」 「 冒 」戴於頭上，引申出覆蓋、籠罩的意思。《玉篇．冃部》：「冒，覆也。」如《詩．邶風．日月》：「日居月諸，下土是冒。」《毛傳》：「日乎月乎，照臨之也。」「 居 」和「 諸 」是語氣助詞。《文選．曹子建〈公讌詩〉》：「秋蘭被長坂，朱華冒綠池。」 頭戴帽子既是帽子覆蓋頭頂，也是頭上頂著帽子，故「 冒 」亦引申為頂著、冒著的意思，如《史記．司馬相如列傳》：「解白刃，冒流矢，義不反顧，計不旋踵。」進一步表示不顧、冒著（危險），如《後漢書．鄧張徐張胡列傳》：「聞車駕當進幸江陵，以為不宜冒險遠，驛馬上諫。」《文選．曹子建〈求自試表〉》：「是以敢冒其醜而獻其忠，必知為朝士所笑。」 「 冒 」表示觸犯、冒犯。如《戰國策．楚策一》：「（蒙穀）遂自棄於磨山之中，至今無冒。」鮑彪注：「冒，謂犯法。」《史記．吳太伯世家》：「遂以其部五千人襲冒楚，楚兵大敗，走。」 「 冒 」表示假冒、冒充。如《史記．游俠列傳》：「臨晉籍少公素不知解，解冒，因求出關。」《漢書．衛青霍去病傳》：「青有同母兄衛長君及姊子夫，子夫自平陽公主家得幸武帝，故青冒姓為衛氏。」 「 冒 」亦表示貪婪。如《尚書．泰誓》：「今商王受，弗敬上天，降災下民，沈湎冒色，敢行暴虐。」《孔傳》：「沈湎嗜酒，冒亂女色。」孔穎達疏：「冒訓貪也。」《左傳．文公十八年》：「縉雲氏有不才子，貪于飲食，冒于貨賄。」 「 冒 」還表示向外透、往上升，如冒煙、冒汗等，乃後起義。例子如北宋蘇軾〈雨後行菜圃〉：「白菘類羔豚，冒土出蹯掌。」《紅樓夢》第86回：「大爺拿碗就砸他的腦袋，一下子就冒了血了，躺在地下。」
Inscriptions from " 冃" from " 目", " 冃" is like a hat, and " eye" is like an eye. Ancients often used eyes to represent the head, and the whole character is like a hat on a head. The original meaning is headwear, that is, hat. Bronze writing is used as a person's name. The " 冃" of the bamboo slips of the Warring States period became " Yin", and the " me" or " self" was changed to " self". One said that " self" is a shorthand for " first", like wearing a hat. The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period are used as a verb to mean wearing a hat, "Guodianjian. "Tao of Tang Yu" Jane 25-26: "The ancient saint is twenty (twenty) and Mao (cap), thirty (30) and (has) family." "Mao (cap)" means crowning, meaning It is said that in ancient times, the saint was crowned as an adult at the age of 20 and married at the age of 30. "Book of Rites. "Qu Li": "Twenty is weak, crown." Also used as a name, "Tsinghua Jian Yi. "Chuju" Jian 7: "Zhi Fen (蚡) Mao (Xiong) Shuai (rate) moved from Ruo (鄀) to live in Fen." "Fang Mao" is the monarch of the Chu Kingdom, namely the king of Chu Li, formerly known as "Xiong Rate" , " Pang" and " Fen" are both place names, meaning that Fen Maoxiong moved from Pang to Fen. "Mandarin. Zheng Yu. "The End of King Ping, Qin, Jin, Qi, and Chu Daixing": "Chu Pingmao is the beginning of Qipu", Wei Zhao's note: "Mao, the grandson of Chu Jihuan, the son of Ruo Ao bears the lead." Examples of the original meaning of " mo" in the handed down literature are like "Han Shu. "Science from Xue Ping and Peng Chuan": "In the first year of the Yuan Dynasty, a man rode in a yellow trolley, built a yellow scorpion, dressed in a yellow coat, dressed in a yellow scorpion, and called himself the prince of Wei." Covering its head." " 旐" is a flag, "襜褕" is an ancient form of clothing. The things that this self-proclaimed Prince Wei wears on his head, body, and uses are bright yellow. Another example is "New Tang Book. Yufuzhi: "Those who take a white gauze, look at the court, hear the lawsuit, and see the guests' clothes." " Mao" was later added with the meaning " scarf" as a " hat" to indicate this meaning, and " taking" It is used for its extended meaning. See " hat". There are also examples in ancient books where "to take" as a verb to mean wearing a hat, such as "Zhan Guo Ce. "Han Ceyi": "Shandong's pawns are attacked by armor to fight." " Bo" is a helmet, and "Mao" means wearing a helmet. "The Book of Later Han Dynasty. Yufu Zhixia: "Ancient cave dwelling in the wild, with furry clothes and fake skins, there is no system." " Mao" is worn on the head, extending the meaning of covering and covering. "Jade articles. "Xianbu": "Come, cover also." Such as "Poetry. Bei Feng. "Sun and Moon": "The sun resides in the moon, and when you go down the earth, it is a risk." "Mao Zhuan": "The sun is like the moon, and it shines upon it." " House" and " Zhu" are modal particles. "anthology. Cao Zijian's "Poems of Public Swallows": "Qiulan was taken by Changban, and Zhu Hua took the green pond." Wearing a hat on one's head means that the hat covers the top of the head as well as the hat on the head. Therefore, "to pretend" is also extended to the meaning of wearing on and off, as in "Historical Records. Biographies of Sima Xiangru: "Resolve the white blade, brave the arrow, do not hesitate, do not turn back." It further expresses disregard and risk (danger), such as "Hou Han Shu. The Biography of Deng, Zhang, Xu, Zhang and Hu: "Wearing that the car is driving into Jiangling, I thought it was not appropriate to take risks, and the post horse would advise." "Selected Works. Cao Zijian "Ask for self-examination": "Because of daring to risk his ugliness and show his loyalty, he must know that he is laughed at by the courtiers." " Risk" means violated, offended. Such as "Warring States Policy. "Chu Ceyi": "(Menggu) then abandoned himself in the Moshan Mountain. There has been no risk so far." Bao Biao's note: "Courage means breaking the law." "Historical Records. "The Family of the Uncle Wu": "Then he attacked Chu with five thousand men. Chu's army was defeated and left." " Risk" means counterfeit, posing. Such as "Historical Records. Biography of Ranger: "The young man from the Jin Dynasty didn't know how to solve it, so he wanted to get out." "Han Shu. "The Biography of Wei Qinghuo Qubing": "Qing has the same mother-in-law Wei Changjun and her sister-in-law. The son-in-law was lucky to Emperor Wu from the family of Princess Pingyang, so Qing Mao's surname was Wei." " Making" also means greed. Such as "Shang Shu. "Thai Oath": "Today, the king of Shang accepts, Fu respects the heavens, sends disasters to the people, indulges in color, dares to tyranny." "Kong Chuan": "Indulges in alcohol, and pretends to be female sex." Kong Yingdashu: "Come on Training is also greedy." "Zuo Zhuan. Eighteenth Year of Wengong": "The Jinyun family has talented scholars, greedy for food and bribery." " Mao" also means to penetrate outwards and upwards, such as smoking, sweating, etc., which is the post-uprising. An example is the Northern Song Dynasty Su Shi's "Raising Vegetable Garden after Rain": "White sock-like lambs and dolphins, croaking out of the soil." Chapter 86 of "Dream of Red Mansions": "The uncle took a bowl and smashed his head, and he immediately bled. underground."

冒字的基本解释

冒
mào
向外透或往上升：冒烟（a.烟往上升；b.发怒）。冒汗。冒尖。
不顾（恶劣的环境或危险等），顶着：冒雨。冒险。冒死。
不加小心，鲁莽，冲撞：冒失。冒昧。冒进（不顾具体条件，急躁进行）。
用假的充当真的，假托：冒牌。冒充。冒名顶替。
复盖：“先设一铁板，其上以松脂、蜡和纸灰之类冒之”。
贪污：“贪于饮食，冒于货贿”。
古同“帽”。
古同“瑁”，玳瑁。
姓。

冒
mò
〔冒顿（d?）〕中国汉初匈奴族的一个君主名。

冒字的康熙字典解释

【子集下】【冂字部】　冒； 康熙笔画：9； 页码：页129第21
〔古文〕　??【唐韻】莫到切【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】莫報切，?音耄。【說文】蒙而前也。从冃目，以物自蒙而前也。謂貪冒若目無所見也。【前漢·翟方進傳】冒濁苟容。【註】師古曰：貪蔽也。【食貨志】舉陵夷廉恥相冒。【註】冒，蔽也。又假稱曰冒。【前漢·衞靑傳】冒姓衞氏。【註】冒爲假稱，若人首之有覆冒也。又所以覆其首。【前漢·雋不疑傳】著黃冒。又【玉篇】覆也，食巾也。又與媢通。【正韻】忌也。【書·秦誓】冒嫉以惡之。又通作瑁。【周禮·春官】天子執冒四寸，以朝諸侯。【註】名玉。曰冒者，言德能覆天下也。又【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】?密北切，音黙。【增韻】貪也。【左傳·昭三十一年】貪冒之民。又犯也。【前漢·衞靑傳】直冒漢圍。又單于名。【史記·匈奴傳】及冒頓立，攻破月氏。又【集韻】【正韻】?莫佩切，音妹。【前漢·司馬相如傳】毒冒鼈黿。【註】毒音代，冒音妹。【韻會】龜屬。身似龜，首尾如鸚鵡，甲有文。

考證：〔【說文】蒙而前。从冃目，以物自

Он состоит из «дня» (форма шляпы, а не «дня») и «глаза» (глаза, представляющие лицо).

гл. А
1) выступать, вырываться, испускать, издавать, идти
冒泡 пузыриться
冒烟 дымиться
冒汗 выступает пот
2) накрывать; покрывать; окутывать; захлёстывать
水犹不冒城郭 вода всё же не заливала предместья города
3) рваться на; врываться, вторгаться; идти напролом против (чего-л.); пробивать, прорывать
直冒汉围 одним ударом прорвать окружение Ханьских войск
4) не считаться с (чем-л.); презирать; рисковать (чем-л.); невзирая на, несмотря на
冒着敌人的炮火前进 наступать, невзирая на орудийный огонь противника
冒霜停雪 несмотря на иней и снег
冒生命危险 рисковать жизнью, пренебрегать опасностью
5) окутаться (напр. дымом); прикрываться (чем-л.)
冒了火 заняться пламенем
冒了他的名儿 прикрыться его именем, под его именем

烟从烟窗冒出 дым вырывается из трубы
2) * ревновать
夫妻相冒 муж и жена ревновали друг друга
3) * ощущать дурноту; рябить в глазах
II mò прил. /наречие
* падкий до наживы, жадный; зариться на чужое
贪冒之民 люди жаждущие наживы, охотники до чужого
III сущ.
1) mào вм. 帽 (шапка, головной убор)
2) mào плат на голову (покойника); убрус
3) mào вм. 瑁 (наконечник на скипетре; скипетр)
IV собств.
1) mào Мао (фамилия)
2) mò Мо (в собственных именах)
Radicals: 日, 目  (sun, eye)
Meaning Mnemonic
When the sun gets in your eye, I dare you to stare at it. I dare you to look right at the sun. I dare you.
Looking at the sun straight on hurts. It’s bad for your eyes and burns your brain. Imagine how painful it is to stare at the sun.
Reading Mnemonic
After you’ve blinded yourself from the dare of looking at the sun and losing sight in each eye, the guy dares you to go bowling (ぼう). You’re blind now, so bowling will be quite the challenge.
Picture yourself bowling without the power of sight. It would be awfully difficult to do well. You’d just have to concentrate really hard on the sound of the pins and determine where you need to throw the ball.
